data.test_name: Motion in a Straight Line Test - 1

1.q_string: The acceleration a (in \(\mathrm{ms}^{-2}\) ) of a body, starting from rest varies with time \(t\) (in s) following the equation \(a=3 t+4\). The velocity of the body at time \(t=2 \mathrm{~s}\) will be:
Displacement \(y\) (in \(m\) ) of a body varies with time \(t\) (in sec) as: \(y=\frac{-2}{3} t^2+16 t+2\). How long does the body take to come to rest?

q_option: The two arrows will be at the same height above the ground at t = 10 s
The two arrows will reach back to their starting points at t = 20 s and t = 30 s
The ratio of the speed of the first arrow and that of the second arrow at t = 20 s will be 2 : 1
The maximum height attained by either arrow will be 980 m
1.q_string: At t = 0, an arrow is fired vertically upwards with a speed of 98 ms-1. A second arrow is fired vertically upwards with the same speed at t = 5 s. Then. which sentence is incorrect:

The acceleration of a particle, starting from rest, varying with time according to the relation \(\mathrm{a}=\mathrm{kt}+\mathrm{c}\). Then the velocity \(\mathrm{v}\) of the particle after a time \(t\) will be:

A ball is dropped from the roof of a tower of height \(h\). The total distance covered it in the last seconds of its motion is equal to the distance covered by it in first three seconds. The value of \(h\) in meters is \(\left(g=10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\right)\)

The driver of a train A moving at a speed of \(30 \mathrm{~ms}\) 'sights another train B moving on the same track at a speed of \(10 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\) in the same direction. He immediately applies brakes and achieves a uniform retardation of \(2 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\). To avoid collision, what must be the minimum distance between the trains?
A body moving in a straight line with constant acceleration of 10 ms-2 covers a distance of 40 m in the 4th second. How much distance will it cover in the 6th second?
A body moving in a straight line with an initial velocity of 5 ms–1 and a constant acceleration covers a distance of 30 m in the 3rd second. How much distance will it cover in the next 2 seconds?
A body, starting from rest and moving with a constant acceleration, covers a distance s1 in the 4th second and a distance s2 in the 6th second. The ratio s1/s2 is:

A car starting from rest is accelerated at a constant rate \(\alpha\) until it attains a speed \(v\). It is then retarded at a constant rate \(\beta\) until it comes to rest. The average speed of the car for its entire journey is:
The displacement of a body from a reference point is given by \(\sqrt{\mathrm{x}}=2 \mathrm{t}+3\) where \(\mathrm{x}\) is in metres and t in seconds. This shows that the body is:
A body goes to \(10 \mathrm{~km}\) north and \(20 \mathrm{~km}\) east. The displacement from initial point is:
The minimum stopping distance of a car moving with no velocity \(v\) is \(x\). If the car is moving with velocity \(2 v\) then the minimum stopping distance will be:
The distance \(x\) covered by a body moving in a straight line in t is given by the relation \(2 x^{2}+3 x=t\). If \(v\) is the velocity of the body at a certain of time, its acceleration will be:

Displacement (x) of a particle is related to time (t) as

x = at + bt2 – ct3, where a, b and c are constants of motion.

The velocity of the particle, when its acceleration is zero, is given by:
The position of an object moving in a straight line can be specified with reference to:

q_option: Position to the right of the origin is taken as positive and to the left as negative.
Position to the left of the origin is taken as positive and to the right as negative.
1.q_string: For motion in a straight line:

q_option: The distance from origin to maximum point
The total length of the path traversed by an object
The distance from origin to minimum point
1.q_string: Path length is defined as.
Path length is a:

q_option: Ways to find velocity without going into the causes of motion.
Ways to find jerk without going into the causes of motion.
Ways to describe motion without going into the causes of motion.
Ways to find acceleration without going into the causes of motion.
1.q_string: In Kinematics we study:
